What do I think about the "end of the universe"? That it is provisional. This is the "final state" of the universe... as far as we could understand in about 2.500 years of science. Does this mean that this will be, for the next billion years, the last conclusion of science? That precisely now, in this merely 2.500 years, we were really able to discover how will be the End of It All? I very much doubt so. In 10.000 years we will laugh (as far as "we" and "laugh" are still applicable concepts) about our current ideas on the "end of the universe". I find much more probable that we discover that we got it all wrong... or that there are way to escape which we cannot possibly imagine now... or that the "universe" is much bigger as we can concieve now, and we can travel. We have billions of years of science to study the problem and find a solution which we have found and understood in only 2.500 - peanuts.

You know...this video right here pretty much proves that all the concern about climate change is completely worthless.  Whether all life on earth ends in a billion years or half a billion or a quarter billion really doesn't matter.  It's just a rounding error compared to the amount of time stretched from the minute life on earth is gone to the minute that the last star sheds it's last photon of light.  A rounding error.  Insignificant.  Yet we're freaking out like... "Oh..if only we can keep life going for a while longer by preventing climate change!  That will MATTER!"  Clearly...nothing matters.  It's all doing to darkness and death and our attempt to hold off the inevitable is likely a subconscious psychological mechanism which we deploy to convince us that we can "cheat death" in some way.  Namely that if we can help "save the world" in some way...the effects of our efforts will somehow allow us to live on in others in the future.

I reject that last bit there.  If the universe is spherical or spheroidal and all mass and energy exploded outward from the big bang, that would explain why it's expansion is accelerating.  It has reached past what you could describe as the universe's equator and is coming together on the other side in the 'big crunch'.  In this model, the universe doesn't end.  It recycles in an infinite loop of big bangs and big crunches.  Your time line would be less linear and more circular.

What happens in the end, a googleplex years from now, may well be a senseless question to ask, for one of two following scenarios will happen:
Either
a) The Universe is a simulation after all, and we discover how to hack it and leave it, to confront the being(s) who started it all,

b) The Universe, being a real entity in its own right, has discovered everything there is to know and the meaning (if any) behind its own existence. There would be no more questions left to answer (a few trillion years or so from now). Content and fulfilled, it's finally prepared to let it all go and find eternal rest in unending oblivion.

We humans, should really consider ourselves as tiny thinking parts of a huge Universe that tries to understand itself (if it's real), or should try to figure out what's behind it (if it's all a simulation).

In the first possibility, we get a deserved rest in the end. In the latter, one could say we're thrown into an adventure that goes on, and on, and on, and on... (not sure which possibility is the most enviable one)

The editing, the narration, the beautifully chosen soundtrack, the way the message was delivered... All absolutely flawless. I dare say this is the absolute best piece of media one could ever produce, since it's built so perfectly to the tiniest detail while talking about the most astronomical thing: us, as beings that fully understand our place and perception of time itself in the universe, which is Existence Itself, which we all share, since we are part of the same Universe that was formed from vaccum space. Maybe a couple Gazillions of years after Our Universe dies, another Universe may be formed, and maybe it will lead to the eventual creation of entirely different beings, Or MAYBE it will be the repetition of our eventual existence, as we know it.
.
.
.
Maybe what we call "different TIME-LINES" are the numerous repetitions of this cycle of beginning of life and its inevitable death, so maybe there has been (or will be) a Universe where EVERYTHING that went down in History went EXACTLY the same way as in our current Universe, but YOU decided not to get out of bed this morning, whilst considering that in OUR timeline, you did indeed get out of bed this morning. Now imagine the INCOMPREHENSIBLE amount of combinations of Universes that could EVER exist, until EVERY possible scenario has happened before! Would that mean something? Would that be some sort of goal? Maybe there are similar TIME-LINES where everything goes down EXACTLY the same way, with the utmost detail. Comparing this phenomenon to rolling a number of dices: the more dices you have, the lower the chances you have of getting the exact same combination of dices, but that is indeed possible. Now think of each dice as an atom, for example, or rather, the smallest form of matter: there would be a combination of Universes where each of the smallest forms of matter would react in a different way, resulting in this Infinite TIME-LINE theory, in other words, I'd be much more inclined to the theory of the Universe where it is constantly dying and coming back to life, because it is possible: it would probably take an "INFINITE" amount of time between the pawn of EACH Universe, but what can we take out of all this?... Probably nothing useful, but it would be pretty neat to know in which loop of the Universe we are!... If it were possible to know what the start is: WHEN did it start? What happened before the spawn of the VERY FIRST Universe? Maybe there were never the conditions that allowed matter to be produced by the 4 Big Forces of the Universe (if I recall that name correctly, there is Gravity and other three), so maybe yes, there might have been a beginning of everything, unless something happened before the FIRST Universe EVERY appeared longer than INFINITY, which happens to be the limit of our capacity as Humans: T I M E. We don't know how long there is between the spawn of two different Universes, so we can't know if something happened before the spawn of the First Universe because, for all we know, we MIGHT just be the First Universe, just to put this in perspective, and our perception of time is so RIDICULOUSLY MINISCULE that we can't either grasp the amount of TIME that went by Before the spawn of Our Universe nor the time that needs to pass After it Dies until a new TIME-LINE would be created. So, in theory, time travel would be possible if we could jump from a Universe to another, where events went down a certain different way, but it's probably impossible for us to grasp a way to make this seem even logically possible to execute, so I'll refrain from going further than this. It's just amazing how many conclusions and theories we can make from our mind alone.

Hmm, heat death is not the only way to end... Besides the obvious statement that all of those are theories, the universe (for all we know) might just revert back to a single singularity with "infinite" mass and constricted in a very small space. After that, maybe for some odd reason a disturbance occurs and there's a Big bang all over again (Big crunch theory)! Or maybe the universe hasn't been created the way we think it did (I personally tend to assume that) and that we are plain and simply wrong about most things... It's absolutely understandable considering we are speculating about a 13 Billion years period ( maybe more, maybe less).
What I'm trying to say here is that we should take all of this information with a grain of salt and, if we are lucky, we might live to see a better theory someday (:

Most interesting video I’ve watched in a long time; the proportional timeline visuals are very insightful.

What’s novel and mind-blowing to me is that, according to this video, life on Earth has been around for 80% of the planet’s existence; the Earth is almost exactly as old as the Sun; the Earth and the Sun have been around for an entire third of the universe’s existence (!); and the Milky Way is almost exactly as old as the universe itself. In other words, we exist in the 1st galactic generation.

Furthermore, life on Earth is already more than 75% through its lifespan; we were born deep into the waning half of Life’s dominion on this planet. The Earth and the Sun are both nearly halfway through their lifespans. By the time the solar system (and therefore the Earth) dies, it will have been around for approximately HALF of the universe’s existence. In other words, we and our solar system belong to the universe’s 2nd generation of solar systems (assuming systems like ours existed during the first 9 billion years of the universe). And even with all this (assuming “a few trillion years” to be 4 trillion for the sake of calculation), the universe is not even ONE HALF OF ONE PERCENT through its productive lifespan of creating new stars! This means that, after this second generation of solar systems comes to a close, the universe still awaits at least more than 400 subsequent generations of solar systems to follow.

I imagine each of these future generations of solar systems will have a similar capacity to generate life; to be the cosmic progeny to our OG status. If our planet (and its contemporary brethren of life-harboring planets across the universe) is not forgotten to time, the ‘universal history books’ will consider us to be The Ancient Ones, from the universe’s infancy.

After the big bang, the universe entered the expanding period where space just keeps growing larger and larger at a slower and slower rate. At some point, (maybe at the death of the universe?? I'm not sure when this is predicted to happen) the universe is expected to enter the shrinking period where it will grow smaller and smaller until it reaches that singularity again. Of course I don't much about this and maybe this idea has been thrown out since I learned about it, but I have think that if it is true, maybe it'll just start all over again with another big bang and a lot of time for a solar system, a sun, and a new earth to form where maybe we get to do it all over again. If things don't get jostled around too much, perhaps the same matter that makes us up now will be in the right spot at the right time for us, the beings that we are now, to re-experience life. Probably not, but it's fun to think about..

People do insist that the universe will be revived out of quantum fluctuations; now, given the fact that entropy (almost) always increases, why would the early hot (and relatively homogeneous) universe arise instead of any other lower-entropy state? And why are we not observing simpler Boltzmann brains (because that theory describes the entire universe as a Boltzmann brain) pop into existence all of the time? The only consistent view would be that they are very improbable.
But then this entails another necessary fact: that there are long-term processes that we do not know about - which is almost certain anyway. Which means that all these long-term predictions about the fate of the universe are extremely uncertain. They rely on the assumption that we do not lack some salient knowledge about processes with long lifetimes.

Actually this may not be entirely correct. How the universe as we know it may not end this way. There is considerable evidence that the universe is expanding; such as the cosmic red shift of far away galaxies due to the Doppler effect working on light due to high speeds and light's wave/particle duality. Nearly every galaxy we can observe has this red shift, and only the ones in our local group exhibit a blue shift (meaning they are traveling at us). With this Hubble Expansion, it can be hypothesized that the universe exists in cycles rather than having a definite end as stated in this video. This cycle begins with the universe at a singularity, a point of infinite density, with all matter in the universe within it. Then a big bang occurs starting the next portion of the cycle. Rinse, repeat.

The past is as real as the future. Think about time in the exact same way you think about the 3D space you live in. Imagine walking down a really long road that is thousands of miles long. Every step you take you are getting further away from where you came from and closer to where you are going. The space behind you is there, it exists, you just walked it, but the space in front of you exists too, it's there, waiting for you to arrive. Well time is the same way. The past exists, you experienced it as the present, about a second ago, a minute ago, an hour ago, a year ago, and that time is still there. The time in front of you is also there. The future already exists. It's there, waiting for you to arrive. The future of time is not something waiting to be fabricated as you move through it. It ALREADY exists! You are not creating space every time you take a step forward, just as you are not creating the future as you move through time. You don't create a timeline, the timeline is already there. Your future sort of predetermined, you just haven't experienced it in the now yet.

Heat Death - sound pretty bad, but you have to imagine just how long "forever" is. In this dead sea of particles there will be random fluctuations. For example if you wait long enough, as in trillions of times the current age of our universe, eventually all of the air molecules in a room will be move to one half of the room. The probability is small, but when you have essentially infinite times, small probabilities become realities.

Now imagine something even less likely - some of the particles assembling to re-form earth and all of its current inhabitants. Even more highly improbable, but as time moves on towards infinity, it will happen. In fact, all things will happen, and they'll happen over and over again. That's just the nature of vast lengths of time.

This is really great video and after watching this video then reading the comments and their accompanying replies have saddened me greatly. Now before I go off on my little rant, let me first point out that I am a bit biased in this but that I also respect people for having their own opinions and beliefs. I am going to start off with how wrong most of the conversation in the comments have been; I just keep scrolling down, further and further, and I keep seeing the same thing: a person that believes in evolutionism, stating their opinions about the video, are being attacked by people who do not believe in the same thing. This is definitely not the case for everyone or every comment, but it is a recurring theme the I have come to dislike. Evolutionism is just a theory for people to believe and an attempt to explain where the universe's origins lie - and the people who state this are being outright attacked by some people. I am by no means discouraging discussion or debate, but rather just stating a personal feeling and I want to get but one point across: if you want to try to get your idea of how the universe came to be, then attacking the opposition will only harden their hearts and that will just fan the flame for an online battle. So please, be respectful of other humans - intelligent life forms that have a mind of their own and their own respective opinions to accompany them - and come about this in a more respectable manner and not put each other down because of mere opinions! I beg of you that if you read this, keep this in mind the next time you want to attack someone with a different belief, be in this very comment section or in politics, take heed of my advice. And if you've managed to read through all of this, then I thank you for taking the time.

With space, there comes time for that space. Time.
That would mean time and space are interconnected. Spacetime.
Imagine that time wasn’t a fixed variable, but could speed up and slow down. Depending on the point of reference.
If time can slow down, could it stop? Imagine time didn’t exist. No time, and no space that fits with the time, Zero time.
Lets say a little began through the Zeroness. With time also comes space. The 3 dimensions are mastered by the fourth dimension time, some guy called Minkowski figured that out. So if time hasn’t started, then space hasn’t started either. Little pops of time spring up. We started from the big bang which is generally agreed to be a singularity. One point. Then bam in a cloud of gas everything was hurtled outwards. eventually the bigger things attracted things then those bigger things attracted more things so on. and forth.
But that one big bang in nothingness started a time and space.
Lets say once time has been started it cannot stop. its the one constant of the universe.
A black hole sucks in everything around it to a single point. What happens after no one really knows. Imagine zero time to be everywhere. Without time you can not have space. So its neither big nor small just there. It is said once a black hole is started it will never stop even when run out of material. If a black hole can suck in everything to a nothingness, would that mean it can capture time? Trying to equal the forces back to zero. Time cannot be stopped. So it pauses on zero time then keeps going to a different time inside the blackhole. The result is a sort of big bang which starts a time and space somewhere. Very much like ours.

So theoretically speaking, everything that happened could possibly be happening again? Watching all these scientific "In a Nutshell" videos made me come to a Hypothesis or Theory. The History, Life and Death, Aliens, Beginnings and Endings are all things to consider. If the galaxy were to repeat itself would everything happen again? Or would it happen differently the next time (Or at all)? Eventually, to my knowledge, everything ends. But haven't ever been asked by myself, does everything Begin? Or Re-begin? Were made of "Star stuff". But could you considerably claim so is everything else? With the Big Bang we have no human being who has seen what happened and only have an idea what happened beforehand through studies and theories. We do however know the basics of what's happening now, in our own little world. We can make ideas and put it out what may or may not have happened. The idea of having a "Now" is pretty complicated in itself, are we experiencing something? Or is it our brain piloting a slab of meat, being able to create and destroy, replicate itself. If emotions were not implemented into our brain would we be ourselves? Time is created by us, Nothing in the Universe gave us time, there is no big clock anywhere floating in space (to my knowledge) that is created by the universe itself. Unless we, considerably are apart of the universe being made out of the stuff creating it. In that case, are you manipulating, expanding, creating the universe with your bare hands? Are we going to keep learning, exploring, creating wars, peace. Only to have it all end, or to be just restarted over again? Personally, Religion seems like a net. It's a way to make us feel more comforting about what happens when we end. Or when we see each other end. I personally am Christian but from the facts I've heard and the theories I'm not sure what to believe. Will their be punishments if it turns out a religion is right and I'm wrong? Or is it all just to begin again? Into different star matter? Is science always correct?

3- The critical mass is exactly enough to keep the universe in perfect equilibrium so no more expansion nor contraction and another heat death.

I love this channel. But I will have to dissagree on that last part. It is physically impossable for the universe to end, and its not hard to understand why: Its because the universe is infinite and there is no "last star". Yes, everything we have ever observed may end, but that does not mean that everything in outer space is dead. Being infinite, there will always be more stars and planets existing or being crated somewhere. We ofton forget that the universe is much bigger than what we can ever observe or even imagine. We live under the illusion that what was created by the big bang is all that exists, but for all we know there might be hundreds of big bangs happening right now, creating uncountable galaxies, only too far away to have any afect on us. Even sientist sometimes underestimate the size of space. The universe may not be able to implode because it has no beginning, end or center. Neither can it expand, solarsystems and galaxys inside it can expand for some reason, but the universe itself is already infinite. Infinity +1 is still infinity.

I'm sure someone has pointed this out before but we really don't know how this universe is going to, well, "end".  It might well be heat death, maximum entropy and all, but that's just one unproven hypothesis. My favorite one is the Big Bounce. It stretches out, and then it comes back in, like an acordeon, or a beating heart. That would also explain what there was "before" the Big Bang, just another iteration of our universe bouncing, and so on. Another thing I'd like to point out: "time" is a property of the universe, our fourth dimension if I'm not mistaken (and there's like eleven of those mind you, according to relativity and string theory, but us hoomans only live in four of them). No universe, no time, so if we're not going to go with the Big Bounce scenario, talking about what there was "before" the Big Bang is pretty pointless.  Outside of the universe there's no such thing as "before". It's freaking mind boggling but that's just how that works.

I just discovered this channel. Generally I like the videos, but I strongly disagree with the final point in this one. Despite everything, we know very little about the universe. We can't say for sure that the universe will die, it is just a theory, based on the knowledge we currently know. There are other theories as well.

Here are some of mine:

1. Who knows, maybe the universe will converge to one single living entity. Everything will be smart matter. And this entity will run trillions of simulated universes, coz it will have infinite energy. :-)

2. Maybe we will find the way to travel back in time to the beginning of the universe and start over.
3. Maybe we can find the way to travel to other universes and start over there and maybe there are infinite universes.
4. Maybe we could create our own universes...

Currently we don't know for sure what is possible and what is not.

My point is: Future matters too! Not just the now. But if you see the cute girl, ask her out anyways. :-) Your future may depends on it.

Don't waste your time, make it something that will benefit you or others.

Our current understanding of space-time and the universe means that asking the question, "What was before the big bang?" is like asking, "What color is 3?" It doesn't make sense. The big bang (whatever it is) marks the start of space-time. Space and time are byproducts of the universe, not the universe of it. There is no "before the universe," as there was no space nor time before the big bang. Furthermore, there is no "beyond the universe" either, as the universe is defined as entirety itself.

great vids btw but im not really sure you can that we dont know what happened before the big bang, it rather implies that there was a a before. most people fall into the common error of placing time and space in the background of everything, but at a universal scale they are more contingent than necessary, time and space both expand out of the big bang. of course we also connect time to causality but this is only true for things inside the universe, the only way we cold do this is if we discovered some hyperspace twhich itself then would have the same seeming limitation. I say seeming because what there is not is a period of time before the big bang which needs something in it but rather a complete lack of timeness, so even if there is something outside it would be extraspatial and extra-temporal, words like event or happen would not apply, nothing could be called before after or at the same time as anything else, any more than you can tell me how hot you are in square kilometers. i hope this helps clarify the problem for anyone reading, these days it does seem if you leave gaps its quickly gets filled with unicorns and wizards, and there are enough real problems to worry about..

The number one term I dislike that so many people who claim religion to be the only 'truth' is the term 'happened randomly'. I am really sorry that you can't wrap your head around this, but nothing about the big bang for instance (not saying it's true of course, there's still arguments to disprove/prove) that says it happened at random.

Random means without cause. It means that effect happens without a cause. Now I (and no one) knows precisely what caused the big bang to explode (if it did happen) but we most certainly know precisely what effect it had and what these effects caused and what those causes effected and so on.

Saying "How am I to believe that this universe arranged itself like it is now randomly and not by design?" is a misconception.

It didn't happen randomly. The galaxies and solar systems and planets and stars and nebula and so on, did not form into their shapes 'randomly'. The universe is the shape it is now because the laws of physics made it that way. So no, it is not 'random'.

HOWEVER, I accept learning about new ideas and theories because at the end of the day, I cannot prove my belief.

I always found it so curious how quickly (relatively speaking) life developed after the formation of the Earth. And for much of the time between the formation of our planet and the first life forms, it was probably too hot and unstable for life to develop in the first place. This may (or may not) indicate that life is actually not that unlikely an event, as long as your time scale is in the billions of years (Earth only had to wait  ~1 billion years between formation and life).

So if the human race is around by the time the universe ends. Do you think that technology and or Spiritual Ascension will enable mankind to travel to different dimensions? Parallel worlds? Time Travel? Perhaps during that time other Alien races will have been discovered and work towards a common goal (Galactic think tank) to "reboot" the Universe? Anyways its great to wonder what will happen to the human race. I just hope someday we can get past the individual greed and look into promoting our species as a whole.

From the moment we are born, we have no memory of the past, we are fresh and new, and from the moment we die, we have no perception of the future, we return to a state similar to that of before we were born. A state of the unknown. I don't know if human beings will ever discover the whole truth about the universe, but in some ways I don't think it matters. I'm confused about this video's absolute determination of the future of the universe. I consider myself familiar with the theories of the expanding accelerating universe, but theory is based on the assumption that the universe is infinite in size or can be extended infinitely. There are other theories that have similar likelihoods to this theory that imply the universe might be finite in size and thus the expanding accelerating universe might still result in a big crunch, thus, resulting in a recycling of the universe. So while we could argue about what will actually happen to the end of the universe until the end of time, at this moment, we can't say with any amount of certainty that it will end one way or the other.

Time, in spite of its physics-based definition and point-of-view, is also a favorite topic of philosophers (philosophy is my favorite subject haha). From a philosophical point of view, there is no such thing as the past or the future, there is only the present. The atoms that made up dinosaurs, dead presidents, and every ancient civilization still exist today: these atoms have merely shifted forms.

The sun we live with is the same sun that shone all those years ago--it has merely burned a bit longer. It seems that nothing really changes but how the ideas we are exposed to have shifted our manners of thinking and manipulating the universe.

It is always the present moment, it is always right now. If we are to predict the future, we should focus on controlling our present. Reality results from an idea, and so by changing our long-lived ideals, traditions, and taboos, we can change the world we live in today.

Who knows where we'll be a hundred years from now.

Okay, firstly, there is no "before" the Big Bang in terms of modern cosmological theory. The Big Bang is the beginning of both Space and Time. There wasn't a "before" because time didn't exist before the Big Bang.

Secondly, Heat Death is only one of many hypothetical ends to the universe. While it does seem the most likely outcome, The Big Rip or The Big Crunch are still totally in the running. Additionally, in the time of the hypothetical Heat Death, space itself will expand meaning Time will take on a different definition as well.

While I do appreciate this video being a general approach to cosmology, it still has some holes in the knowledge. Please take this into consideration in the future.
